match.venue: Sir Vivian Richards Stadium, North Sound, Antigua

commentary.line: 97.2   Jordan to J Holder, no run
97.1   Jordan to J Holder, no run, good length outside off, Holder presses forward to block and the ball nearly takes the outside edge, that one held its line
96.6   Tredwell to Ramdin, no run, that kept a bit low, but Ramdin went back and blocked it well
96.5   Tredwell to Ramdin, no run, well tossed up outside off, Ramdin gets forward and blocks
96.4   Tredwell to Ramdin, FOUR, fraction short outside off, Ramdin makes room and cuts hard through cover, beats the chasing fielder, who was Ballance
96.3   Tredwell to Ramdin, no run, shortish on the stumps, Ramdin hangs back and punches to short mid-wicket
96.2   Tredwell to Ramdin, no run, more flight, Ramdin smothers it back down the track
96.1   Tredwell to Ramdin, no run, tossed up on the stumps, Ramdin gets forward and nudges it to short mid-wicket
95.6   Jordan to J Holder, no run, another comfortable front foot block to point
95.5   Jordan to Ramdin, 1 run, angling in on the hips, tucked to deep mid-wicket
95.4   Jordan to Ramdin, no run, Ramdin gets forward and presses the good length delivery back down the track
95.3   Jordan to Ramdin, no run, full and outside off, Ramdin gets forward and shoulders arms
95.2   Jordan to Ramdin, no run, short of length outside off, Ramdin defends to cover
95.1   Jordan to Ramdin, no run, good length outside off, left alone
94.6   Tredwell to J Holder, no run, fraction short outside off, pushed off the back foot to cover
94.5   Tredwell to J Holder, no run, ooh! Close. Tredwell lures Holder into the big drive, the ball dips and bounces in front of the shot, the inside edge misses the stumps
94.4   Tredwell to J Holder, no run, leans forward to block
94.3   Tredwell to J Holder, no run, loud shout for lbw and England don't review. Turned too much and rapped Holder on the pads. He was pressing forward to block and replays show it was going down
94.2   Tredwell to J Holder, no run, tossed up outside off, Holder gets forward and defends to cover
Slip and a short leg in. Also silly mid-off in too
94.1   Tredwell to J Holder, no run, tossed up outside off, Holder drives to mid-on
James Tredwell [27.0-11-57-1] is back into the attack
93.6   Jordan to Ramdin, no run, full outside off, Ramdin gets forward to push off the front foot to cover
93.5   Jordan to Ramdin, no run, pitched up outside off, Ramdin gets forward to drive and edges it onto his arm, went too hard at it
93.4   Jordan to Ramdin, no run, short down leg, Ramdin pulls and misses, Buttler felt it flicked something on the way, but there was nothing
93.3   Jordan to Ramdin, no run, short of length on the stumps, Ramdin hangs back and clips to the right of mid-wicket where Trott makes a good stop
93.2   Jordan to Ramdin, no run, full and inswinging, Ramdin makes sure he doesn't fall over, flicked to mid-wicket
93.1   Jordan to Ramdin, no run, back of a length on the stumps, Ramdin hangs back and defends
Chris Jordan [10.0-4-23-1] is back into the attack
92.6   Stokes to J Holder, no run, on a good length and outside off, Holder gets forward and presses it to short cover

92.5   Stokes to J Holder, FOUR, now Holder gets a boundary throgh gully, short of length outside off, Holder punches with an open face and it beats the man diving to his left. Still third man is vacant and the partnership grows
92.4   Stokes to J Holder, no run, low full toss outside off, Holder gets forward and drives with an open face, finds point
92.3   Stokes to Ramdin, 1 run, on the middle and leg line, tucked to the right of square leg, easy single
92.2   Stokes to Ramdin, no run, angled in on the stumps, hint of inswing, Ramdin is on the shuffle but blocks it to mid-on
92.1   Stokes to Ramdin, no run, short of length outside off, Ramdin stands tall and blocks
91.6   Broad to J Holder, no run, full and straight on the stumps, Holder closes the face of the bat and the leading edge doesn't carry back to Broad, mid-off runs around to prevent any runs
91.5   Broad to Ramdin, 1 run, Ramdin shuffles across and tucks it through mid-wicket, single
Back over the wicket now
91.4   Broad to Ramdin, no run, dug in short, Ramdin ducks under that one
91.3   Broad to Ramdin, no run, short of length on the stumps, Ramdin blocks
91.2   Broad to J Holder, 1 run, short of length outside off, Holder defends to point, easy single
91.1   Broad to J Holder, no run, from round the wicket now is Broad, dug in short on the stumps, Holder blocks it down
90.6   Stokes to Ramdin, no run, good length outside off, Ramdin opens the face of the bat and defends to point
90.5   Stokes to Ramdin, no run, full and on the stumps, Ramdin mistimes the on-drive to mid-on
90.4   Stokes to Ramdin, FOUR, beautiful on-drive from Ramdin. He doesn't fall over, shows the full face of the bat and punches the drive past the stumps at the non-striker's end, races away
90.3   Stokes to Ramdin, no run, pitched up outside off, Ramdin gets forward and drives hard, but Stokes leaps and intercepts
90.2   Stokes to J Holder, 1 run, good length on the stumps, Holder wrists it with soft hands near the vacant short mid-wicket area for a single
90.1   Stokes to J Holder, FOUR, not a good comeback from Stokes in his new spell, down leg, Holder flicks it away to the fine leg fence. Easy pickings
Ben Stokes [9.0-0-27-0] is back into the attack
89.6   Broad to J Holder, 1 run, Holder defends with soft hands in the gap at cover, takes the single
89.5   Broad to J Holder, no run, Holder goes back and across, tucks it to short leg, kept it down
89.4   Broad to J Holder, no run, short down leg, left alone
89.3   Broad to J Holder, FOUR, edged but with soft hands and bounces in front of Bell at 2nd slip and races away. On a good length outside off, Holder played it down and did well to get a boundary
89.2   Broad to J Holder, no run, another short delivery, down leg though, Holder lets it go
89.1   Broad to J Holder, no run, short on the stumps, near chest-height, Holder stands tall and drops it down with soft hands
88.6   J Anderson to Ramdin, no run, wide of the crease, angled in, defended off the back foot
88.5   J Anderson to J Holder, 1 run, short on the stumps, Holder pulls and controls it well, down to deep mid-wicket, for a single
88.4   J Anderson to J Holder, no run, back of a length outside off, Holder stands tall and blocks
88.3   J Anderson to Ramdin, 1 run, back of a length on the hips, nudged down to deep backward square leg

88.2   J Anderson to J Holder, 3 runs, good length outside off, Holder opens the face of the bat and guides it square of the wicket, Stokes gives chase and tracks back, pulling it before the boundary ropes
88.1   J Anderson to J Holder, no run, very full outside off, Holder drives and picks out mid-off
87.6   Broad to Ramdin, no run, very short outside off, Ramdin ducks and lets it go

87.5   Broad to J Holder, 1 run, in the air but doesn't carry to deep square leg. Short on the stumps, Holder top-edges the pull and it falls agonisingly short of the on-rushing Trott from the deep. He tried his best to get closer to the ball, but couldn't get there in time

87.4   Broad to Ramdin, 3 runs, fumbled by Anderson now to his right as he lets it go through his hands, a thick inside edge as Ramdin went hard on the drive, it went wide of mid-on. The fumble gives three
87.3   Broad to Ramdin, no run, pitched up on the stumps, Ramdin shows the full face of the bat and on-drives, but Anderson slides to his left at mid-on to field
87.2   Broad to Ramdin, no run, bouncer, Ramdin ducks under it
87.1   Broad to Ramdin, no run, inswinger, Ramdin defends off the back foot
86.6   J Anderson to J Holder, no run, angled in on a good length on the stumps, Holder defends solidly

86.5   J Anderson to J Holder, FOUR, magnificent drive. Overpitched by Anderson, Holder gets forward and drives wide of cover, put away with so much grace and poise. Looks so good when he plays, does Holder

86.4   J Anderson to J Holder, no run, more indecision from Holder and more bad luck for Anderson. He has his hands on his head. Holder was late in leaving that corridor of uncertainty delivery, the ball takes the bottom of the bat and goes to the keeper on the bounce

86.3   J Anderson to J Holder, no run, what a delivery and Holder acknowledges it with a nod back at the bowler. Holder is comprehensively beaten. Pushed forward to play drive and the ball angled in around off and held its line, lovely probing delivery
86.2   J Anderson to J Holder, no run, good length and nips back in, Holder defends to cover
86.1   J Anderson to Ramdin, 1 run, on the pads, flicked to fine leg

That will be drinks as well. West Indies are hanging in. But England still have all the time in the world to take these last four wickets. Must say one was pretty disappointed to see Blackwood get out the way he did. Very poor way to give it away especially after the innings he played in the first essay when he showed admirable patience
85.6   Broad to J Holder, no run, angled in on a fuller length, Holder covers the line well and blocks solidly off the front foot to cover
85.5   Broad to J Holder, FOUR, that is wristily played by Holder. Stands tall and whips it over mid-wicket as the back of a length delivery was angled in on the hips
85.4   Broad to J Holder, no run, good length outside off, Holder gets forward and then leaves at the last moment
85.3   Broad to J Holder, 2 runs, pitched up outside off, Holder plays another pleasing cover drive, on the rise and gracefully hit for a couple to deep extra cover
85.2   Broad to J Holder, no run, that is another expansive shot attempted and Holder is lucky that he has inside-edged it onto the thigh pad. It wasn't short to be pulled
85.1   Broad to J Holder, no run, back of a length outside off, Holder stands tall and defends to cover
84.6   J Anderson to Ramdin, no run, flicked to the right of Ballance at square leg, he runs and dives to his right to stop it. Holder sends Ramdin back
84.5   J Anderson to Ramdin, no run, good length on the stumps, keeps a bit low, Ramdin defends well to mid-on
84.4   J Anderson to J Holder, 1 run, angled in, Holder gets forward to defend, but gets a thick inside edge to fine leg
84.3   J Anderson to J Holder, no run, good length outside off, Holder plays a fine drive off the front foot but straight to the fielder at short cover
84.2   J Anderson to Ramdin, leg byes, 1 run, down leg again, Ramdin misses the flick, off the thigh pad and it's a leg bye
84.1   J Anderson to J Holder, 1 run, down leg, flicked to fine leg, for a single
83.6   Broad to Ramdin, no run, good length outside off, Ramdin gets forward and shoulders arms
83.5   Broad to Ramdin, FOUR, now Ramdin gets the on-drive wide of Anderson. The feet moved nicely and he put the full one through the mid-on region. Pleasing boundary
83.4   Broad to Ramdin, no run, inswinger, Ramdin wants to come forward, then goes back as the length is short, blocked
83.3   Broad to Ramdin, no run, that was well stopped by Anderson at mid-on. Went quickly to his left and intercepted a firm on-drive from Ramdin
83.2   Broad to Ramdin, no run, pitched up and hint of nip back in, Ramdin shuffles across and pushes it to mid-on
83.1   Broad to J Holder, 3 runs, pitched up outside off, Holder gets forward and gently drives wide of mid-off, by the time the fielder tracks back, they have taken three
Stuart Broad [13.0-4-32-1] is back into the attack

82.6   J Anderson to Ramdin, FOUR, so close but no cigar! Full and swinging away late, Ramdin is opened up and gets an edge on the drive, a thick one too but it flies wide of Root at the wider of the two gullies. It races away to the fence. Anderson has his hands on his head
82.5   J Anderson to Ramdin, FOUR, short and wide outside off, Ramdin doesn't miss out, cut into the gap at cover for a boundary. Poor delivery and Ramdin gave it the treatment
82.4   J Anderson to Ramdin, no run, back of a length outside off, Ramdin dabs it to point
82.3   J Anderson to Ramdin, no run, outswinger, Ramdin pushes it awkwardly towards point
82.2   J Anderson to Ramdin, no run, short of length outside off, Ramdin stands tall and blocks
82.1   J Anderson to Ramdin, no run, good length outside off, swinging away, left alone
James Anderson [14.0-2-39-1] is back into the attack
Anderson has the new ball and his family wait in anticipation of the record being broken. He is setting the field. Two slips and two gullies in place
81.6   Jordan to J Holder, no run, Jordan is looking for the inswinging yorker, but another low full toss, driven to short cover
81.5   Jordan to J Holder, 2 runs, pitched up outside off, Holder gets forward and drives with an open face to deep extra cover, two taken
Jordan loses his run-up and has to rebowl that one
81.4   Jordan to J Holder, no run, goes for the attempted yorker, but again gets it down leg, Holder leaves
81.3   Jordan to J Holder, no run, angling in on the stumps, worked to mid-wicket
81.2   Jordan to J Holder, no run, length outside off, Holder gets forward and presses it to short cover
81.1   Jordan to J Holder, no run, horrible delivery down leg, short and Holder didn't have anything to do with it
Still Jordan to continue
England didn't take the new ball because Anderson wasn't on the field. He is back now
80.6   J Root to Ramdin, no run, down leg, flicked to mid-wicket
80.5   J Root to Ramdin, no run, tossed up on the stumps, Ramdin gets forward and blocks
80.4   J Root to Ramdin, no run, on the stumps, Ramdin shuffles across and defends
80.3   J Root to Ramdin, no run, sees the ball sliding across him and shoulders arms
80.2   J Root to J Holder, 1 run, leans forward and opens the face of the bat to steer it wide of the gully, single taken
80.1   J Root to J Holder, no run, flatter from round the wicket, defended off the back foot
The new ball is due now. But still Root to bowl as England don't take it. Three men around the bat for Holder
79.6   Jordan to Ramdin, no run, good inswinging yorker, tails in late and Ramdin digs it out
79.5   Jordan to J Holder, 1 run, defended with an open face wide of Tredwell at gully, he fumbles and gives away a single
79.4   Jordan to J Holder, no run, Holder pushes it off the back foot to short cover
79.3   Jordan to J Holder, no run, on a good length and outside off, Holder presses it to short cover
79.2   Jordan to J Holder, no run, good length outside off, Holder hangs back and defends to point
Jason Holder, right handed bat, comes to the crease

79.1   Jordan to Blackwood, out Caught by Buttler!! Blackwood plays a horrid stroke and gets out. That was certainly unnecessary at this stage - with the new ball due next over. He charges Jordan and tries to slog to leg, gets a thin bottom edge and taken low by Buttler. The tail is exposed and England scent victory. Blackwood c Buttler b Jordan 31(60) [4s-4]
Jordan to Blackwood, THATS OUT!! Caught!!
78.6   J Root to Ramdin, no run, very full on the stumps, Ramdin digs it out to short cover

78.5   J Root to Ramdin, 2 runs, Ramdin pulls and hits Ballance on the hand at short leg. Ballance was evading the ball by turning his back and it was struck powerfully, it hits the end of the fingers and the protector on the finger flies off. He is in pain, but shrugs it off and continues
78.4   J Root to Ramdin, no run, tossed up outside off, driven to mid-off
78.3   J Root to Ramdin, no run, sliding across Ramdin who goes back and punches to short cover
78.2   J Root to Ramdin, 2 runs, fraction short on the stumps, Ramdin rocks back and pulls to deep mid-wicket. Two taken
Slip and a short leg in place
78.1   J Root to Ramdin, no run, tossed up from round the wicket, Ramdin gets forward and blocks
Joe Root [7.0-4-8-2] is back into the attack
77.6   Jordan to Blackwood, no run, short of length outside off, Blackwood hangs back and blocks
77.5   Jordan to Blackwood, FOUR, smashed away. Driven on the rise and a powerful blow wide of the diving Root at short cover. The ball whistled away to the fence in a flash
77.4   Jordan to Blackwood, no run, pitched up outside off, Blackwood shoulders arms
77.3   Jordan to Blackwood, no run, the ball is nipping around, Blackwood plays a bit around his front pad but manages to flick it to mid-wicket
77.2   Jordan to Blackwood, no run, quicker and nips back in a tad, Blackwood is forward to push and gets an inside edge onto the body. Bit of extra bounce too for Jordan
77.1   Jordan to Blackwood, no run, sliding down, Blackwood can't connect with the glance
76.6   Tredwell to Ramdin, no run, flighted delivery outside off, Ramdin pushes it back down the track
76.5   Tredwell to Ramdin, no run, Ramdin shuffles across and blocks another delivery on the stumps
76.4   Tredwell to Ramdin, no run, tossed up on the stumps, defended
76.3   Tredwell to Ramdin, 2 runs, tries to repeat the lofted shot over mid-on, mistimes it, but clears mid-on. A couple though
76.2   Tredwell to Ramdin, FOUR, now cuts through cover. Dropped short outside off, Ramdin went back and hammered the shot in the gap. Gets four for it
76.1   Tredwell to Ramdin, FOUR, superbly hit straight down the ground, tossed up from Tredwell, Ramdin went back over Tredwell and got a clean connection. That is a calculated blow
75.6   Jordan to Blackwood, no run, well outside off, easy leave
75.5   Jordan to Blackwood, no run, Blackwood looks pretty solid, a front foot block
75.4   Jordan to Blackwood, no run, short of length outside off, Blackwood hangs back and defends
75.3   Jordan to Blackwood, no run, outside off, left alone
75.2   Jordan to Blackwood, no run, good length outside off, Blackwood gets forward and presses it to short cover
75.1   Jordan to Blackwood, no run, short of length outside off, punched to short cover
74.6   Tredwell to Ramdin, no run, bit of bounce for Tredwell, but Ramdin handles that from the crease despite not coming forward
74.5   Tredwell to Ramdin, no run
74.5   Tredwell to Ramdin, no run, very full outside off, eased to mid-off off the front foot
74.4   Tredwell to Ramdin, no run, now drives well, but straight to the fielder at cover
74.3   Tredwell to Ramdin, no run, Ramdin looks to drive and the bottom hand takes over, mistimed to mid-off
74.2   Tredwell to Ramdin, no run, slower on the stumps, Ramdin gets forward and nudges it to the right of the bowler
74.1   Tredwell to Ramdin, no run, tossed up outside off, pushed back to the bowler
73.6   Jordan to Ramdin, leg byes, 1 run, sliding down leg, Ramdin fails to flick and it runs off the thigh pad behind square
73.5   Jordan to Ramdin, no run, pitched up outside off, Ramdin shows the full face of the bat and punches it back to Jordan
73.4   Jordan to Ramdin, no run, another inswinger, but it is outside off, so no issues for Ramdin who lets it go
73.3   Jordan to Ramdin, no run, full outside off, Ramdin reaches out to drive and finds Root at short cover
73.2   Jordan to Ramdin, no run, pitched up outside off, driven back without any timing to Jordan
73.1   Jordan to Ramdin, no run, good length nips back in, Ramdin covers the line and defends
72.6   Tredwell to Blackwood, no run, shortish outside off, punched wide of point for a quick single
72.5   Tredwell to Blackwood, FOUR, Blackwood is showing off his strokes. Races down and goes over cover, hit flat and another boundary for the impressive young man
72.4   Tredwell to Blackwood, no run, flatter outside off, Blackwood handles that off the back foot
72.3   Tredwell to Blackwood, no run, wide of the crease and flighted delivery outside off, spins back in, Blackwood is forward to defend, misses and is hit on the body
72.2   Tredwell to Blackwood, FOUR, lots of air outside off, Blackwood sees the flight and then goes over Tredwell's head. Neatly played and safe too
72.1   Tredwell to Blackwood, no run, tossed up outside off, Blackwood uses his feet and drives to mid-off
James Tredwell [24.0-10-39-1] is back into the attack
71.6   Jordan to Ramdin, no run, good length outside off, Ramdin shoulders arms
71.5   Jordan to Ramdin, no run, short of length, nipping back in, not hitting off, Ramdin shoulders arms
71.4   Jordan to Ramdin, no run, short outside off, Ramdin cuts and finds point, hit straight to the fielder
71.3   Jordan to Ramdin, no run, pitched up outside off, Ramdin drives with a closed face to mid-on
71.2   Jordan to Ramdin, no run, Jordan nearly gets through Ramdin, the front leg goes forward and then across, the bat comes down at an angle, but the inside edge onto the pads saves him
71.1   Jordan to Ramdin, no run, good length on the stumps, Ramdin shuffles across and defends back down the wicket
Welcome back. It could well be the final session of the game. Can West Indies drag the game on? Jordan to resume proceedings. Three slips in place...

James Anderson came level with Ian Botham's record tally of 383 Test wickets when he got a well set Samuels edging to gully. On either side of that wicket, the spinners struck. Tredwell forced Devon Smith to chip one to mid on while Root got the dangerous Chanderpaul just before lunch. West Indies needed a big stand today to try and save the Test. England have done well to strike at regular intervals. They could not have asked for a better session. Can West Indies last the day? Can Anderson break Botham's record? All that coming up soon. Stay tuned.
That will be lunch on day 1
70.6   J Root to Blackwood, no run, floated up on off, Blackwood gets forward and presses it down
Last ball before lunch
70.5   J Root to Blackwood, no run, pushed through by Root, Blackwood again keeps it out off the back foot
70.4   J Root to Blackwood, no run, flatter and on the stumps, Blackwood handles that off the back foot
70.3   J Root to Blackwood, 2 runs, fraction short on the stumps, Blackwood rocks back and pulls to deep mid-wicket, in the gap, but not well-timed, so a couple
70.2   J Root to Blackwood, no run, pitched up outside off, Blackwood gets forward and drives to mid-off
70.1   J Root to Blackwood, no run, sliding on from round the wicket, Blackwood feels for it and nearly nicks it through to the keeper, the angle did him in
69.6   Stokes to Ramdin, FOUR, Stokes misses the yorker, turns out to be a low full toss, Ramdin flicks through mid-wicket and gets four
69.5   Stokes to Ramdin, no run, pitched up outside off, Ramdin gets forward and drives to short cover
69.4   Stokes to Ramdin, no run, good length outside off, Ramdin shows the full face of the bat and defends to the left of Stokes
69.3   Stokes to Ramdin, no run, pitched up and inswinging, Ramdin drives it back to Stokes
69.2   Stokes to Ramdin, no run, inswinging, Ramdin is careful and blocks with bat and pad close together
69.1   Stokes to Blackwood, 1 run, full outside off, Blackwood gets forward and defends with an open face to backward point, takes the single
68.6   J Root to Ramdin, no run, very full, almost yorker length on the stumps, Ramdin keeps it out
68.5   J Root to Ramdin, no run, bounces a bit extra, Ramdin goes back and defends to short leg
Four men around the bat now
68.4   J Root to Ramdin, no run, tossed up on the stumps, Ramdin gets forward and turns it to short mid-wicket
68.3   J Root to Ramdin, no run, flicked to short mid-wicket
68.2   J Root to Ramdin, no run, full on the stumps, dug out to the right of the bowler
Denesh Ramdin, right handed bat, comes to the crease

68.1   J Root to Chanderpaul, out Lbw!! Root has struck and that could be the game-changing wicket. Sliding on with the arm from round the wicket, Chanderpaul in trying to defend got his bat slightly outside the line and didn't make contact. Rapped on the pads in front of all three. Chanders to had to review and did so, but he knew his fate. No inside edge onto the pads too. Chanders was dead there. Root does a Usain Bolt and runs away in celebration. Chanderpaul lbw b J Root 13(48) [4s-1]
J Root to Chanderpaul, THATS OUT!! Lbw!!

Big moment in the game. Root has got Chanderpaul in front. Trapped lbw. He is reviewing though. Root runs away in delight and is seen pumping his fist vigorously. Three Reds and Chanderpaul is gone. What a wicket that is
A few words exchanged between Blackwood and Stokes. Chanders uses his experience to talk to Blackwood and calm him down. That's Chanders' value to the side
67.6   Stokes to Blackwood, no run, inswinging yorker from Stokes, Blackwood digs it out
67.5   Stokes to Blackwood, no run, short of length outside off, Blackwood hangs back and wrists it softly to the right of the bowler
Slight delay as umpire Bowden's hat flies away in the breeze
67.4   Stokes to Blackwood, FOUR, edged and wide of the 2nd slip. Went to ground quickly though. Full and wide outside off, Blackwood drives and gets lucky
67.3   Stokes to Blackwood, no run, another solid front foot block
67.2   Stokes to Blackwood, no run, pitched up outside off, Blackwood gets forward and drives hard to short cover
67.1   Stokes to Blackwood, no run, good length outside off, Blackwood gets forward and presses it to short cover

66.6   J Root to Chanderpaul, no run, well played by Chanderpaul. It was bowled from the front of the hand by Root, pitches outside off, in the footmarks and bounces, but Chanderpaul defends with soft hands off the back foot
66.5   J Root to Chanderpaul, no run, very full on the stumps, pushed back to Root
66.4   J Root to Chanderpaul, 2 runs, full on the stumps, Chanderpaul flicks it through mid-wicket for two

66.3   J Root to Chanderpaul, no run, loud shout for lbw and England are pondering a review. They don't take it. It was fired in outside off, Chanderpaul got outside the line and padded it away, no way that was out and rightly not given
66.2   J Root to Chanderpaul, no run, another one on the stumps, defended back down the track
66.1   J Root to Chanderpaul, no run, floated up on the stumps from round the wicket, pushed back to Root
Joe Root [4.0-3-4-1] is back into the attack
65.6   Stokes to Blackwood, no run, short of length outside off, Blackwood gets back to punch, gets a bottom edge to gully
65.5   Stokes to Blackwood, no run, good length outside off, Blackwood was late in shouldering arms, it runs off the bat face to the slip cordon, but on the bounce
65.4   Stokes to Blackwood, 2 runs, angling down, Blackwood stays back and clips it down to fine leg, for a couple. The man was very square and had a lot of ground to cover
65.3   Stokes to Blackwood, no run, pitched up outside off, driven hard and straight to mid-off
65.2   Stokes to Chanderpaul, 1 run, that is softly nudged by Chanderpaul, with a closed bat face to square leg
65.1   Stokes to Chanderpaul, no run, short of length on the stumps, Chanderpaul defends to short cover
64.6   Tredwell to Blackwood, no run, slower and loopier on the stumps, Blackwood gets back and defends
64.5   Tredwell to Blackwood, no run, ugly from Blackwood. He comes down the track and hacks it without any timing back to the bowler
Round the wicket to Blackwood

64.3   Tredwell to Chanderpaul, no run, flatter on the stumps, Chanderpaul blocks
64.2   Tredwell to Chanderpaul, no run, Chanderpaul uses his feet and defends softly
Tredwell is now bowling from over the wicket to Chanderpaul

The players are out there. Nice and bright. Sunny too. Tredwell to begin proceedings. Samuels on strike. Slip and a short leg in place. The players are waiting for the clock to tick over to 10am local. Samuels too waits patiently...

Marlon Samuels talking to Nasser Hussain before the start of the day feels that West Indies will play positively and go for the target. He says that if he gets his eye in he will go for runs. He is very confident that his side can draw/win the game. Also feels that it may spin as the day goes on

Pitch report: 'It has held together incredibly well' says Mike Atherton referring to the pitch. There will be a little bit of spin for Tredwell and Root. The pitch is very very slow. 'It will be hard work to get people out' signs off Athers

It sets up for a cracking day's play. Yesterday Gary Ballance shrugged off his recent poor form to make a fine Test ton. His innings enabled England to declare and set a target of 438 as Cook declared after Jordan's wicket. Brathwaite went early but Smith and Bravo held firm, before the introduction of Root got Bravo out.

A fascinating final day in prospect as West Indies look to survive 90 overs and come out with a draw. It won't be easy against Anderson, Broad, Jordan and Tredwell. Tredwell will be key as there was turn and spin for Root when he bowled yesterday. Devon Smith hung in to reach a stubborn fifty but he needs to carry on not only for his sake but also for the team. The wickets of Chanders and Blackwood will be the ones that England will be craving for.

Stumps, Day 4: Gary Ballance stroked his way to bag his 4th Test ton as England set a target of 438 for West Indies. In reply, the hosts lost Brathwaite early but a good second wicket stand between Bravo and Devon Smith resurrected them. The former fell late in the day to Root giving England a boost but Smith has managed to hang in there with a fine fifty. With 8 wickets in hand and 340 to score on the last day, West Indies are definitely behind the eight-ball but will be looking to fight it out. They need a couple of good partnerships to try and save the game. The pitch has held up nicely so it will not be all that easy for England either. The last day promises to be a good one. Join us again tomorrow to catch all the action.

34.1   J Root to Darren Bravo, out Caught by Jordan!! What a bowling change! What a catch! Root is on a run, jumps and punches the air in delight. Lapse in concentration from Bravo. Very full and outside off stump, Bravo looks to drive, the ball goes off a thick outside edge, Jordan is so alert at slip, he dives to his right and takes a wonderful one-hander. So a wicket late in the day for England will lift the mood in their camp. Bravo can't believe that he's been dismissed and walks off slowly. Credit to Jordan for reacting quickly as it was travelling off the edge. In fact, replays how that he took the catch behind his body. Darren Bravo c Jordan b J Root 32(87) [4s-3]

The players are making their way out to the middle. Anderson will start the proceedings after tea.

It has been another long session for West Indies. Gary Ballance got his fourth Test ton and Buttler got a quickfire fifty as England stretched the lead to 437. Ballance played a gem of an innings and held the innings together while Buttler played the perfect hand when England were pushing for a declaration. Stuart Broad getting Brathwaite just before the break was the icing on the cake. West Indies have degenerated rapidly today. It will need a stubborn innings from someone to prevent a quick finish. Join us in a short while for more action.
That will be tea

Lots of chat from the Englishmen behind the wicket

Same field for Devon Smith too

Kraigg Brathwaite and Devon Smith are at the crease. Kraigg Brathwaite is on strike. J Anderson will open the attack
Welcome back... England are in a huddle. The West Indian openers are out there too. Anderson has the new cherry. Three slips and a gully in place

Then Roach got a wicket but it was a no-ball, and off the very next delivery, he got Jordan out, caught in the deep - a swirling catch in the breeze. West Indies will have to face a minimum of 130 overs to save/win the match. Whether they can hang on remains to be seen. We will be back shortly for the West Indian reply...

So the target for West Indies is 438. Timely declaration from England too as West Indies will come out to bat for 20 minutes before the tea break. A crazy 10 minutes or so there. You won't see a worse review than the one Holder took against Buttler for a caught behind appeal. The ball was miles away from bat. Even he had a chuckle about it, realising his error. Then Steve Davis made a big error giving an lbw when the ball pitched outside leg and was missing leg by a long way, off the next ball.

85.6   Roach to Jordan, out Caught by Darren Bravo!! England have declared with that wicket. Swung away to leg, lots of height on that and Darren Bravo covered good ground to his left at deep mid-wicket and held on to the swirler. Falls down after taking and seems to be in a bit of pain. But all is ok as they trudge off. Jordan c Darren Bravo b Roach 13(17) [6s-1]
Roach to Jordan, THATS OUT!! Caught!!

85.6   Roach to Jordan, no ball, Roach bowls Jordan but it is a no-ball. What a waste that is! It was slower on the stumps and Jordan swung and missed, the ball clips the bails but replays show that Roach had overstepped. Disappointment for West Indies and Roach

Kemar Roach [13.0-1-47-0] is back into the attack

84.5   J Holder to Buttler, no run, Buttler was shuffling across and Holder fired in the yorker, following the batsman, but it had pitched outside leg and rapped Buttler on the outside of the pad, Steve Davis gave it out, but replays prove that he was wrong. Buttler was quick to review. The ball ran away to the fine leg fence, but officially the ball is deemed to be dead so will count as no runs

Now Buttler is given out lbw. He reviews. Is the ball missing leg? Yes it is. Hawk-Eye shows it has pitched outside leg. Buttler survives. Steve Davis has made a bad decision and it will be rightly overturned

84.4   J Holder to Buttler, no run, Holder followed Buttler with a full ball, Buttler swung and missed. Daylight between bat and ball. Holder forced a review from Ramdin and in the end they were smiling at the incredulity of the decision

Review time. Has Buttler got an edge to Ramdin? Worst ever review. Miles between bat and ball. Ridiculous review and Holder is seen having a wry smile. What was that? Never seen such a poor review being taken before
84.3   J Holder to Buttler, FOUR, Buttler has slapped that away. Goes right back and then hammers the pull through mid-wicket. The short ball sat up to be hit and Buttler didn't miss out

Welcome back. The players are out in the middle. What total will be enough for England? Buttler is padded up to come in next.

England are running away with the game. Gary Ballance and Joe Root got their fifties early in the first session. Root fell soon after chopping one on off Holder. But Ballance and Stokes have helped England consolidate thereafter. Their partnership rattled along at a brisk pace and England are slowly getting into a position from which they can push for a declaration later in the day. Ballance will be eyeing his hundred soon after lunch. Join us for all the action in a little while.
That will be lunch as well

Curtly Ambrose is seen having another animated chat with his wards. The two batsmen walk out to the middle. Jerome Taylor will be starting off from round the wicket. He bowled an outstanding spell to get both Cook and Trott, can he repeat that today? Here we go...

Some news from the venue. It rained earlier in the day and the covers were on. But the groundstaff are seen removing them - so we shouldn't have a delay. Let's see whether play will start on time. Peter Moores is seen having a chat with Jos Buttler. We will keep you posted on all the developments...

James Tredwell was the pick of the England bowlers taking four-for, undeservingly missing out on a five-for. He lured both Chanderpaul and Holder into playing expansive strokes when they were well-set and was a major factor in his side getting a first innings lead. When England came out Trott and Cook both flopped once again falling to Jerome Taylor. Bell was run out soon after leaving his side at 52/3. Then the two Yorkshiremen - Ballance and Root got together and have put on an unbeaten stand of 64. England lead by 220 and would be looking towards a declaration sometime around tea today

Jermaine Blackwood showed he is a player of immense potential and one that West Indies can bank on in the future. Showing immense powers of concentration and displaying loads of patience with the bat he notched up his maiden Test ton to take West Indies closer to the England's first innings total. Then as it happened so often in the past, the West Indies tail folded quickly leaving the young man stranded. A lead of 104 - a precious one - was garnered by England.

Jermaine Blackwood's maiden Test ton was definitely the highlight of day 3. The youngster showed remarkable resilience to remain unbeaten till the end and keep England's lead to 104. It was a shame that he did not receive adequate support from the other end. James Tredwell proved the unlikely strike force as he bagged a four-wicket haul including that of the dangerous Chanderpaul. Jerome Taylor gave England some early jitters with the wickets of Trott and Cook but England fought back steadily after that. Ian Bell fell cheaply as well but Ballance and Root have ensured that England finished the day well on top. West Indies need to restrict England quickly tomorrow but that will be a very tough task. Join us again tomorrow to see how they fare.

Coming back to the run-out chance, Ramdin wasn't sure whether he took the bails off in his first attempt and that's why he disturbed the stumps for the second time. Bell was left stranded in the middle and took a lot of time to go back.

A slip and a FSL in place

18.4   Benn to Bell, out Bell Run Out!! Bell has run himself out here. It was the slider on the pads, Bell pushes at it, gets an inside edge onto the pad and the ball rolls away towards the square leg region. Bell set off for the single, but Ballance wasn't interested. Bishoo from short fine runs to his left, picks the ball and fires in the throw at the striker's end. Bell has to run back to his crease, but falls short as Ramdin takes the bails off in the second attempt. A needless wicket thrown away by the English batsmen and the West Indians are delighted. Bell run out (Devendra Bishoo/Ramdin) 11(35) [4s-2]
Benn to Bell, THATS OUT!! Run Out!!

He doesn't have a good inswinger, hence he opts for the scambled seam ball to surprise the batsman, this does jag back in sharply, bit of extra bounce as well, Bell hops and looks to fend and it goes off the thigh pad past the keeper. Two great balls first up to Bell!

Ian Bell, right handed bat, comes to the crease

6.4   Jerome Taylor to Cook, out Caught by Benn!! This is a big wicket and the crowd love it. The scrambled-seamer from Taylor, full and outside off stump, Cook leans forward and plays for the inswinger, but the ball holds its line and he gets a thick outside edge that flies straight to gully. Cook played a long way away from the body and was pushing at it with hard hands. The England captain has managed to score 24 runs in this Test match. Cook c Benn b Jerome Taylor 13(22) [4s-2]
Jerome Taylor to Cook, THATS OUT!! Caught!!

4.6   Jerome Taylor to Trott, out Caught by Ramdin!! Jerome Taylor gets Trott for the second time in the match and he jumps and punches the air in delight. Poor return to Test cricket for Trott as he could score just 4 runs in the match. Nice outswinger on a fuller length, Trott was on the walk as he looked to drive, the ball takes a healthy edge and flies to Ramdin's right and he makes no mistake and takes a good low catch. This is just the start West Indies wanted. Trott c Ramdin b Jerome Taylor 4(15)
Jerome Taylor to Trott, THATS OUT!! Caught!!

Cook and Trott are at the crease. Cook is on strike. Jerome Taylor will open the attack
Three slips and a gully in place.
Welcome back. Some animated words from Curtly Ambrose in the West Indies team huddle. The England openers make their way out

The players have taken tea as well as the West Indian innings ended. They (England beginning the second innings) should've played for 10 minutes - I don't get why they have taken the tea break now. Anyway handy lead for England and they would be looking to build on it in the last session. It should be a long session too. Do join us shortly for that. Stay tuned...

The innings folded so quickly. The last three wickets falling in 11 balls. Before that Holder gave it away. But not before Blackwood made a fine maiden 100. He carried his bat and walks off to deserved cheers. This innings should be the making of him as a young Test batsman. At one stage when Blackwood and Holder were playing, it looked like West Indies may get closer to England's total. But now England have a 104-run lead.

112.6   J Anderson to Benn, out Caught by J Root!! Has Benn got a glove on that? Looks like it. He is walking off. Blackwood remains unbeaten. Angled in on the pads, Benn swung and it may have gone off the glove, Root at short leg moves quickly to his left at short leg to take it. Anderson takes two - still two away from Sir Ian Botham's all-time record for England. Benn c J Root b J Anderson 2(7)
J Anderson to Benn, THATS OUT!! Caught!!

112.5   J Anderson to Benn, no run, 'the sweep hook' is how Nasser Hussain on air describes the shot. Short down leg, Benn sitting under that flaps at that and misses. Root and Benn have a laugh about that shot. That looked ugly and ungainly
112.4   J Anderson to Benn, 2 runs, angling in, Benn plays the pick up flick well over mid-wicket for a couple of runs
112.3   J Anderson to Benn, no run, bouncer, Benn ducks
112.2   J Anderson to Benn, no run, yorker length outside off, dug out by Benn
From round the wicket now
112.1   J Anderson to Blackwood, 1 run, inswinging yorker on the stumps, Blackwood almost falls over, digs it out through mid-wicket, wants two but it isn't there
The field is spread for Blackwood
111.6   Tredwell to Benn, no run, slightly short outside off, Benn initially came forward and then went back to cut, missed
'Carrom ball, carrom ball' shouts Buttler to Tredwell
111.5   Tredwell to Benn, no run, tossed up from round the wicket, Benn stretches forward and blocks
Sulieman Benn, left handed bat, comes to the crease

111.4   Tredwell to Jerome Taylor, out Jerome Taylor Run Out!! A thick outside edge runs to the left of Broad at backward point, Jerome Taylor set off looking for the quick single, Blackwood knew there wasn't a single there, sent Taylor back, a sharp throw does the job catching the diving Taylor short. That's two wickets in three balls. Jerome Taylor run out (Broad/Buttler) 0(2)
Tredwell to Jerome Taylor, THATS OUT!! Run Out!!
Has Jerome Taylor got himself run out? He is walking. What an utter waste that is. Gone
111.3   Tredwell to Jerome Taylor, no run, almost a carbon copy of Roach's dismissal. Just that Jerome Taylor pushed out and missed. Rather than getting an edge
Jerome Taylor, right handed bat, comes to the crease

111.2   Tredwell to Roach, out Caught by Buttler!! Tredwell breaks through. Bowled from wide of the crease, it goes straight on after pitching, lures Roach forward into the defence, a thin outside edge is held by Buttler. The resistance of Roach is over. Roach c Buttler b Tredwell 5(33)
Tredwell to Roach, THATS OUT!! Caught!!
111.1   Tredwell to Roach, no run, tossed up outside off, Roach gets forward and defends

110.6   J Anderson to Blackwood, FOUR, what was that? Blackwood comes down the track and then heaves Anderson over mid-wicket. Dragged it off the inside half, completely mistimed but got away as it was in the gap. Looked very ugly as Blackwood played that but the result is what matters eventually

110.5   J Anderson to Roach, 1 run, short, Roach gets inside the line and awkwardly pulls the short ball on the stumps, to fine leg. There was a fielder at backward square catching but Roach eluded him

Actually Blackwood stretched his arms after reaching 100 and punched the air in delight. He has showed immense grit, concentrated hard and even though he has had slices of luck against Stokes, he has made this innings count. Not easy to get a Test hundred against Anderson, Broad and Co. Looks like a talented young batsman. Good head on his shoulders too
103.6   Tredwell to Roach, 3 runs, Roach gets forward to defend and lets that run off the face past slip, by the time Broad got there, they take three

Kemar Roach, right handed bat, comes to the crease

103.3   Tredwell to J Holder, out Caught by Ballance!! Tredwell strikes. Another soft dismissal. Much like Chanders, Holder has gifted England a wicket. Against the run of play. He skips out and opens the face on the drive, can't keep it down and it's a simple catch at stomach height to the tumbling cover fielder. Tredwell may seem innocuous but he has the knack of picking up important wickets. J Holder c Ballance b Tredwell 16(44) [4s-2]
Tredwell to J Holder, THATS OUT!! Caught!!

Back over the wicket now to Holder

103.1   Tredwell to Blackwood, 1 run, Blackwood take a bow! There is the maiden Test hundred. A moment to savor for the young Jamaican. Pushes it down to long-off. No great celebrations from Blackwood. He removes his helmet. Raises the bat and acknowledges the applause from his mates. Holder walks up to Blackwood and hugs him. This is a moment he will never forget for the rest of his life
Cook is back on the field now. Single available to long-off

The physio is out to check on Holder now. He was hit on the left-arm off the first ball of that Jordan over. Magic spray and they are ready to continue again. Still no arm guard for Holder or Blackwood

Are England going for a review? Cook asks Buttler. Yes they are. Blackwood given not out on the lbw call. Has he got an inside edge onto the pads? Is it sliding down leg? Very full delivery on middle and leg, Blackwood misses the drive, it could be umpire's call. Let's see. Waiting for Hawk-Eye. To the naked eye it looks like there is no edge. Umpire's call. Clipping leg. Blackwood survives

Ben Stokes [16.0-3-41-0] is back into the attack
92.6   Jordan to Blackwood, no run, Blackwood ends the over with a solid front foot defence

Welcome back. Holder and Blackwood walk out. They punch gloves before strolling to the middle. Still bright and sunny. Jordan to restart proceedings. Two men back for the hook
Match well balanced at the moment. We will be back in a while to bring you all the updates from the second session of play. Do stay tuned...

Ramdin survived for a while but he became a victim of Broad's short ball ploy. Blackwood has gritted it out to stay unbeaten. He has been hit on the arm and survived a barrage of short pitched bowling. But he hasn't thrown it away and showed he is made of sterner stuff. He got one more life when Tredwell dropped him off Stokes at gully. With Holder capable of batting well, Blackwood will be looked upon by his team to take them closer to England's first innings total

The players walk off for lunch. Another gripping session of play today. 26 overs have been bowled and it has been an even session. England set a trap for Shiv Chanders - two men catching close in at short cover and he fell into it. He got a boundary through there, but chipped one in the same over. That was a big blow to West Indies, just before the second new ball was due.
91.6   Broad to J Holder, 1 run, defended into the gap at cover, they take a single and it will be lunch on day 3

Flicked to the right of Ballance, he was expecting the ball to come slowly, but it came quicker and he could only stretch his right hand, hoping to catch, but the ball hit the hand and went down. Very difficult chance, those need to stick. Slice of luck for Holder
Holder can bat. We saw that during the World Cup

Jason Holder, right handed bat, comes to the crease

Broad to Ramdin, THATS OUT!! Caught!!
Now round the wicket

Immediately Blackwood calls for medical attention. Hit just above the elbow. An ice pack is being brought out. Blackwood isn't wearing an arm guard. Magic spray and some pressing from the physio should do its job. Slight delay in play

Anderson and Broad will look to rip through the late middle-order and tail as quickly as possible with the new ball

The players are out there in the middle. Anderson will start off proceedings. Blackwood on strike. Bright and sunny now. It had rained before the start of play and rained heavily too. But that all has stopped and it is a glorious day now

Pitch report: It is a very good surface. Perhaps the best day for batting. There is a little bit of rough outside off stump for the left-handers. 'It is a pretty good day for batting' signs off Nasser Hussain

Hello and welcome to day 3 of the first Test. Generally day 3 is considered to be the moving day in a Test. So let's see whether things move at pace or will it be another slow day like yesterday. Blackwood has looked good, apart from the solitary occasion when he edged a catch to slip. But that turned out to be a no-ball and he was reprieved. Chanders is looking as solid as ever at the other end. England toiled hard but didn't get much assistance from the pitch. Will it be any different today? Stay tuned to find out...

It was West Indies' day yesterday. First they replicated the success of the first day's opening session with the ball - bowling tight lines, being disciplined and then playing on the batsmen's patience. They were rewarded with the last five wickets for just 58 runs as England were bowled out for 399. Then they came out with the bat and even though they have lost four wickets, the partnership between Chanderpaul and Blackwood has raised hopes of matching England's total.

Another attritional day of Test cricket at the end of which England are ahead when the bigger picture is viewed but West Indies are not out of it yet. Not as long as Chanderpaul is out there fighting. Jermaine Blackwood too has shown enough promise and stomach for a fight. The duo added 56 runs in the final session after England removed two well set batsmen - Brathwaite and Samuels - early in the last session. West Indies' bowlers did well to restrict England to 399 in the first session of the day. The reply started steadily but suffered a wobble in the middle. That has been culled for the time being but they are still 244 adrift at the end of day 2. A good contest between bat and ball in the offing on day 3. Do join us again for all the action.
It will be stumps on day 2

Welcome for the final session.

Tea, Day 2: It has been another good session for West Indies. The openers began sedately before Devon Smith became Anderson's 381st Test victim. Darren Bravo hung in for a while before falling to Jordan. Brathwaite was rock solid all through but runs were at a premium. The arrival of Marlon Samuels changed that too. His batting came as a breath of fresh air as West Indies continued to make steady progress. Samuels averages 71 against England. He will be the key for the hosts in the next session as well. Join us in a bit to see how that pans out.

England are appealing for a catch. Is that bump ball? The umpires converge and Steve Davis draws a small rectangle in the air. We are going to the third umpire. No issues with Stokes' footing. Oh that looks like it's bounced. NOT OUT flashes on the screen

Welcome back. A testing session awaits the Windies for we have seen Anderson and Broad swinging it. Let's see whether West Indies can win two sessions in a row

Another excellent morning session for West Indies. Curtly Ambrose gave them a spirited pep talk at the start of the day and his bowlers responded superbly. Jerome Taylor got the crucial first breakthrough early in the day when he got a well set Ben Stokes for 79. Roach and Holder carried on the good work as England lost their last five wickets for just 58 runs today. That was also largely helped by a 38-run last wicket stand between Anderson and Jordan. England finished just one short of 400, a pleasing session for the WI bowlers but the batsmen need to back it up now. It won't be easy in conditions that are helping the seamers. Can they fight it out? Join us again in the next session to find out.
That will be lunch on day 2

A nice moment from the England team as they allow James Anderson to lead the side onto the field. Anderson's family is there to mark the special occasion of him reaching 100 Tests. Fine gesture from the England team. They are in a huddle and break out. The West Indian openers are out there too. A tricky 10 minutes or so...

But they need to do it with the bat to back up what their bowlers did. It won't be easy against Anderson and Broad. A couple of overs to go before players take lunch. We will be back shortly for the West Indian reply

Curtly on the sidelines is a happy man. He is waiting for his team members and claps them in. He pats a couple of them on the way back. His pep talk before the start of the day has worked. England were 341/5 at stumps on day 1 and West Indies have taken the last 5 wickets for 58. The last wicket added 38 of those. A very satisfactory morning for West Indies

Are West Indies taking the review? Yes they are. Not out given for an lbw call. Did Jordan get outside the line? No inside edge onto the pads. Pad first and looks to be in-line. Waiting for Hawk-Eye now. The third umpire is taking a lot of looks. This will take some time. Bowden rules it not out. The third umpire thinks there was an inside edge onto the pads. That could be the only reason for giving that not out
It is bright and sunny at the moment. All the bad weather seems to have gone out of the window

Hello and a warm welcome to day 2. We don't have good news to bring you first up. There is a heavy shower at Antigua at the moment. We will keep you posted on whether we will get a prompt start or not. Do stay tuned...

Even the excellent Roach and Holder were guilty of bowling short and wide as they flagged under the onslaught. One lost count of the number of times Benn bowled short and wide as well as Bell's late-cutting. What began as a fine effort turned out to be a poor one until Roach out of nowhere produced a screamer off his final delivery of the day to get Bell out. That wicket evened the scales a bit even though it was advantage England at the end of day 1.

Then inexplicably Benn started bowling short and wide outside off at the start of the second session and the pressure began to ease. Slowly but surely Bell and Root got their eye in and the runs started to come. The third session got even worse for the hosts as the tired attack was taken to all parts of the North Sound Stadium in Antigua. Runs flowed from Bell and Stokes with the former notching up his 22nd Test hundred. Stokes supported Bell well with an attacking fifty of his own.

Day 1 was a tale of two different sessions. West Indies were outstanding in the morning session when they scalped three wickets and bowled with relentless control and precision. There was hardly a bad ball as Taylor, Roach and Holder probed away on or around off. Intense pressure was built up on the batsmen and England were three down at lunch.

Ian Bell's fantastic 143 scuttled all the good work done by West Indies in the first session. They were 49/3 at lunch but England fought back through a 177-run stand between Bell and Root. The former scored his 22nd Test ton and gave a masterclass in turning things around through some old-fashioned albeit clinical batting. He dug in when the pacers were bowling well and cashed in when they tired. Root gave him excellent support in the second session as West Indies fell apart. Kemar Roach was the standout bowler and he proved it once again with a stunning ball late in the day to bag Bell. West Indies were superb with the new ball in the morning but leaked quick runs with the second new ball. Ben Stokes stroked a free-flowing fifty in the last session as England completed the turnaround by scoring 174 runs. The wicket of Bell must boost West Indies but they still have a lot of work to do tomorrow to prevent a tall first innings score. Thanks for joining us today. Do come back again tomorrow to catch all the action.
That will be stumps on day 1. Root is all smiles in the dressing room. Stokes walks off raising his bat to the crowd

Nothing he could've done. It bounced and Bell just shook his head before walking away. Was very disappointed to have got out so late in the day. Needed that kind of a delivery to get him out

Welcome back for the post-tea session. The players are making their way out to the middle.

No doubts about how each session went today. West Indies had England under a lot of pressure at 49/3 in the first session. Ian Bell and Joe Root fought back superbly in the next session to put things on an even keel. Both struck fifties, added 133 runs and remained unbeaten as England scored 127 in the second session without losing a wicket. The juice in the pitch wore off considerably and West Indies could not manage to maintain the intensity that they held in the first. Suleiman Benn was guilty of bowling too many short balls and allowed the pressure to ease on England. One session to go to determine whose day it is. Stay tuned to see how it pans out.

Welcome back. Should be another gripping session. Let's see whether West Indies can continue their good work.

It has been a near perfect exhibition of top class fast bowling from West Indies in the first session. Jerome Taylor got the early breakthrough when he stunted Trott's comeback and sent him back for a duck. Kemar Roach then took over the mantle of creating pressure under overcast conditions. Cook was castled for 11 by the leader of the pace attack. Jason Holder kept up the pressure coming in as first change and reaped Ballance's wicket after Roach built up pressure at the other end. A very brief shower interrupted the game but not much time was lost. The pacers continued to exploit the juice in the track to keep England on the mat. Joe Root and Ian Bell had no option but to try and survive. Run-scoring probably did not even cross their mind and neither was it allowed to by West Indies. That explains the scoreline at lunch. England crawling at a run-rate around two per over and battling for survival. All West Indies at the moment and England need to dig deep to fashion a comeback today. If West Indies can maintain the same intensity in the next two sessions, it will make for fascinating viewing. Stay tuned.
That will be lunch on day 1

The umpires are back and we should restart pretty soon. Replays showed that Ballance played a very bad stroke. Maybe he thought he could get a boundary after he saw the width on that delivery. Credit to West Indies though, all the three seamers have bowled excellently. They have hit the right line and lengths and made the Englishmen's job very difficult. Deservedly they have picked up three wickets. Won't be easy for Root first up as he walks out along with Bell.

It should be a short delay as the sun breaks out once again. As I type that, the covers are coming off. Very minor delay that. But expect rain once again in the day. Meanwhile Bell is talking to someone in the English set-up who is advising the Warwickshire man. Bell is all ears

Hoho! As soon as Ballance is out, the heavens have opened. Rain and the covers are on. 'It is going to be a long interruption' says David Gower on air. The groundstaff are quick to get the covers on and drape the pitch

16.5   J Holder to Ballance, out Caught by Darren Bravo!! Holder strikes. Third wicket for the West Indies. After leaving so well, he has played a very poor stroke to get out. Nice ploy by the Windies to come round the wicket and test Ballance. Roach did all the hard work, softened him up and now Holder reaps the rewards. It was full and very wide of off, Ballance normally would've left that, but he chose to play a drive, the edge is found and straight to Bravo at first slip who clasps it at around chest height. Throws the ball away in delight. Ballance c Darren Bravo b J Holder 10(46)
J Holder to Ballance, THATS OUT!! Caught!!

A minute's silence from the 22 players and the umpires in memory of the late Richie Benaud. A poignant moment!

Cook: "We are going to have a bat first. If we can get through the first session, should be a good wicket to bat on. Trott comes in to open and Stokes at 6. We have gone for Tredders, he has waited a long time and he has done very well so far on the tour. It is great to have him and it is an amazing effort to come back from where he was in Brisbane and hope he does well this week (on Trott). Incredible effort, he is the most skilful bowler I have seen. That alongside his work ethic and work hard as he does, hopefully we can make it special for him this week as well (on Anderson)."

Ramdin: "We are going to have a bowl first. We want to exploit the moisture early on. Hopefully our new ball bowlers will get some assistance and get a few top order wickets and put the middle order under pressure. Not on this, no (when asked if they thought about playing two spinners on this). Phil Simmons has been motivating us to win Test matches."

Pitch report: The last time these two sides met in this venue the game lasted 10 balls and just 34 minutes. There has been only one game since that abandoned 2009 game. Pretty bare, not much grass. Obvious bat first pitch. 'Very bare pitch' signs off Mike Atherton
Teams:

West Indies (Playing XI): Devon Smith, Kraigg Brathwaite, Darren Bravo, Marlon Samuels, Shivnarine Chanderpaul, Jermaine Blackwood, Denesh Ramdin(w/c), Jason Holder, Jerome Taylor, Kemar Roach, Sulieman Benn
England (Playing XI): Alastair Cook(c), Jonathan Trott, Gary Ballance, Ian Bell, Joe Root, Ben Stokes, Jos Buttler(w), Chris Jordan, Stuart Broad, James Tredwell, James Anderson
West Indies have won the toss and have opted to field

Stat: West Indies have won just two Tests out of their last 27 meetings against England. However, they've lost just one series in the last 47 years against England at home. They won 1-0 when England toured in 2009.
Weather update: A high of 28 degree celsius is predicted. The weather department says that there is a 80% chance of rain.

England: The question doing the rounds is whether England will go with Trott to open or give the left-handed Yorkshireman Adam Lyth his debut. Lyth had a tremendous county season last year so it will be an interesting decision. Ben Stokes will be in at 6 replacing the injured Moeen Ali. James Tredwell may get the nod over Adil Rashid for the lone spinning spot.

Pre-match team news, West Indies: Legspinner Devendra Bishoo makes a comeback into the West Indies side after three years while the selectors have also named uncapped wicketkeeper-batsman Shai Hope and fast bowler Carlos Brathwaite in the 14-man squad. There is no Chris Gayle which means Devon Smith will open. Darren Bravo who was injured during the World Cup is back as well. It is a battle for the 6 spot between Blackwood and the newcomer Shai Hope. Also it will be interesting to see whether West Indies go in with two spinners or three quicks.

West Indies' captain Denesh Ramdin feels that Chanderpaul's experience in constructing long innings would be crucial to West Indies putting up big scores in the three-match series. "His (Chanderpaul's) experience is second to none, especially with all those matches he has played at international level," Ramdin said. "I'm sure he will go on to get the most runs for West Indies as a Test player and I'm sure that's his goal but with with his experience in the middle order, batting all those balls, we need other guys to bat with him to get partnerships and get big totals so we have opportunities to win matches."
"But it's something special to coach your own country. And once we get to that level of doing everything professionally I think the talent will come through."
"I know we're not in the best of places right now."
"It's been frustrating [to witness West Indies' decline]. It would be for anyone who has represented West Indies. It's been disappointing to see the way we've played."

Let us now focus on the new West Indian coach, Phil Simmons, a bit. After coaching Ireland for eight years, Simmons took up the West Indian role just before this series. He is of the opinion that only through hard work can the West Indies rise from their position as No. 8 rated Test team to a place in the top three. "It's been well documented that we're not in a good place as far as cricket is concerned," Simmons admitted to ESPNCricinfo. "We need to get back in that good place."

"You have got to keep things in perspective and you've got to understand that there are no guarantees in life. Things aren't just going to work out your way and you've just got to roll with the punches sometimes. Being better at that is something I feel that I have and I've worked really hard at a few things, a culmination of things had to come together for me to be able to get here. I'm really pleased."

The 33-year old is not content, however, by just making the England squad. He now wants to contribute towards Test match wins. "It's not all about high fives and handshakes. It's about doing some hard yards and winning Test matches for England.

"It feels very nice. It's a culmination of a lot of hard work for a couple of months with the (England) Lions and with Warwickshire," Trott told ecb.co.uk. "It's always pleasing to get the opportunity to come back and play for England, it's something I've worked really hard for. It's nice to be here, but the hard work continues and trying to prepare and earn a place in the Test team."

Another man who will have attention focussed upon him will be Jonathan Trott. The right-handed batsman, who infamously pulled out midway through the 2013-14 Ashes series in Australia due to a stress-related illness, is making his comeback in this series. It has been a tough 15 months for the Warwickshire batsman but he is looking forward to put that behind him.

Despite his great success, Anderson believes he may not be the bowler he was before getting charged with a Level 3 breach of the ICC Code of Conduct after his alleged shoving incident with India's Ravindra Jadeja. "I've definitely been different since that incident," Anderson told ESPNCricinfo. "It probably affected me during the World Cup. "It didn't affect me during that India series because there was still that real determination to win; I was aggressive without being over the top. But in the World Cup, there was a constant sense that the ICC were watching," he said.

"We want to express ourselves and put smiles back on people's faces," Anderson told BBC Sport. "The 100th Test is a huge landmark for a player. I'm really looking forward to experiencing it. But the record will take a back seat. We have a really important period ahead trying to get some wins and get some form after a disappointing winter, so concentrating on that is the most important thing. It's a huge Test match for us as a team. We've got a lot of hard work to do out here, we know it is going to be tough, but we're really excited about the challenge."

He may have lost a bit of pace but makes it up with his potent swinging pedigree. When the ball swings, he along with Dale Steyn are the two best exponents of the art of swing bowling. Anderson will become the 12th Englishman to play 100 Tests, but said that he would like to put his personal achievements behind and concentrate on putting 'the smile back on people's faces' after a poor season.

One man though who will be the cynosure of all eyes will be James Anderson. This Test will be Anderson's 100th match and he's also just four wickets short of beating Ian Botham's record tally of 383 Test wickets for England. Anderson has come a long way from the blonde-haired kid who tore Pakistan apart in the 2003 World Cup. Since then his career has seen many ups and downs but over the last few years, he has been England's premier fast bowler and the leader of the pack.

England though won the last Test series they played, against India and their captain Alastair Cook desperately needs to fire. He is under a lot of pressure coming into this series having not made a Test ton for the last 31 innings. His last hundred came against New Zealand in May 2013 at Leeds. If he fails to get runs this series, then several more questions will be asked not only of his captaincy but also of his batting spot.

Both sides are coming on the back of poor results currently. England had a shocking World Cup where they failed to reach the quarter-finals losing to Bangladesh and getting knocked out. Alastair Cook wasn't a part of that campaign but still the appointment of Eoin Morgan didn't make any difference to their World Cup hopes. A lot of ink has been spent analysing, dissecting and understanding where England have gone wrong. The criticism some times went overboard but that's how it is in England. West Indies reached the quarters but they were thrashed by New Zealand in that game. On current form it is a battle between two teams trying hard to regain their lost glory.

08:53 Local Time, 12:53 GMT, 18:23 IST: It is back to whites and red ball cricket! Test Cricket is back after a flurry of short format cricket. It is West Indies v England and it is kicking off at the Sir Vivian Richards Stadium in Antigua. England are playing a Test match after a gap of nearly 8 months. In that period they have played 25 ODIs if you include the two World Cup warm-up games as well. West Indies on the other hand faced South Africa in a Test series in January.

Preview
The World Cup hangover has hardly come down but the bandwagon rolls on as West Indies and England prepare to lock horns in another format while also tackling a host of internal problems. England will have to look past their horrendous World Cup campaign, sweeping changes in the ECB and tide past the varied issues that accompany it.

West Indies have for long been tussling with players drifting away from the longest format and a wide variety of administrative problems of their own. Denesh Ramdin's men will have to put all that behind when they walk out for the first of the two Tests at Antigua.

West Indies have won just two Tests out of their last 27 meetings against England. However, they've lost just one series in the last 47 years against England at home. They won 1-0 when England toured in 2009 but Ramdin's current side bears a pale resemblance to the side which won six years ago. England are ranked third in the ICC Test rankings and won their last Test series against India quite comprehensively. That will count for little now as a lot of water has passed under the bridge since July 2014.

Venue: Sir Vivian Richards Stadium, Antigua

Date: April 13, 2015

Time: 1400 GMT

Team news:

England

This will be James Anderson's 100th Test and he's also just four wickets short of beating Ian Botham's record tally of 383 Test wickets for England. The leader of the pace attack will be keen to make a mark on this special occasion and it's a testimony to his excellence over the years that he still remains England's premier bowler. He's formed a potent combination with Stuart Broad and the duo's form will be key to England's success in the Caribbean. The wrist spin of Adil Rashid is likely to be preferred over James Tredwell's offspin with the pitch likely to being on the slower side.

Selecting the right batsmen will pose more problems for the England think tank. Jonathan Trott is back in the squad after battling mental fatigue during the 2013/14 Ashes in Australia but did not make a pressing case for immediate selection in the two practice games ahead of the first Test. England's practice games were shambolic with the the players joining in with the St Kitts XI to try and make for competitive match practice. Trott's 72 in the tour opener at St Kitts looks to have tilted the scales in his favour over the uncapped Adam Lyth, meaning that he and Alastair Cook - who has not scored a century in 31 Test innings - could be the openers.

Probable XI

1 Alastair Cook (capt), 2 Jonathan Trott/Adam Lyth, 3 Gary Ballance, 4 Ian Bell, 5 Joe Root, 6 Jonathan Bairstow, 7 Jos Buttler (wk), 8 Chris Jordan, 9 Stuart Broad, 10 James Anderson, 11 Adil Rashid

West Indies

Phil Simmons' first assignment as head coach of West Indies will not be an easy one. He's had a lot of success with Ireland but his home side are currently placed eighth in the Test rankings and pushing them up will be top priority. Ramdin has a lot of responsibility to shoulder and will be banking on the experience of Shivnarine Chanderpaul and Marlon Samuels to lead the way with the batting. In Darren Bravo, they have a youngster with immense potential and the rest of the batting unit will be focussing on batting around these three.

Kemar Roach has been West Indies' most successful bowler in recent years and remains a pacer who can produce a match-turning spell. Carlos Brathwaite, the uncapped pacer, is likely to be picked ahead of Jerome Taylor given his form recently while Jason Holder will fill in the role of the third seamer. Devendra Bishoo has been brought into the side after three years and is likely to get the nod ahead of Suleiman Benn who had a lacklustre series against South Africa late last year.

Probable XI

1 Kraigg Brathwaite, 2 Devon Smith, 3 Darren Bravo, 4 Marlon Samuels, 5 Shivnarine Chanderpaul, 6 Jermaine Blackwood, 7 Denesh Ramdin (capt/wk), 8 Jason Holder, 9 Kemar Roach, 10 Devendra Bishoo, 11 Carlos Brathwaite
Teams:

England (From): Alastair Cook(c), Jonathan Trott, Gary Ballance, Ian Bell, Joe Root, Jos Buttler(w), Ben Stokes, Adil Rashid, Liam Plunkett, Stuart Broad, James Anderson, Chris Jordan, Adam Lyth, Jonathan Bairstow, Mark Wood, James Tredwell

West Indies (From): Kraigg Brathwaite, Devon Smith, Darren Bravo, Marlon Samuels, Shivnarine Chanderpaul, Denesh Ramdin(c/w), Jermaine Blackwood, Jerome Taylor, Sulieman Benn, Kemar Roach, Carlos Brathwaite, Devendra Bishoo, Jason Holder, Shai Hope
